title: How to Make Traditional Sindhi Kadhi

steps.headline: Wash and soak kokum in warm water.
Heat oil in a pan.
steps.description: Add the mustard, cumin, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves and asafoetida one by one.

steps.headline: Add gram flour.
steps.description: Stir continuously, until the color of the flour changes to a bit dark brown (not burnt brown). The consistency of oil and gram flour should neither be solid nor too liquid. [Image:Brown 1.jpg|center|550px]]

steps.headline: Add half a litre of water and turmeric powder.
Allow it to boil for 2-3 mins.
Add the potatoes and lotus stalk (since these veggies take time to soften).
Add the french beans, green peas, cluster beans, and cauliflower florets.
Smash the kokum with soft hands.
steps.description: Add the water along with kokum, and the remaining half litre of water.

steps.headline: Add the eggplant and okra; they may get smashed if added earlier.
steps.description: Many ladies fry okra in oil and make it crisp so that they don't break in kadhi, but fry them occasionally depending on their freshness.

steps.headline: Heat 2 tsp of oil and add red chili powder.
steps.description: Turn off the flame, sprinkle over Kadhi and garnish it with coriander leaves.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Sindhi kadhi goes with rice, spicy potato wedges and sweet boondi as side dishes, but you could also eat it as is.

text: Wash and soak kokum in warm water.  Heat oil in a pan. Add the mustard, cumin, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves and asafoetida one by one. Add gram flour. Stir continuously, until the color of the flour changes to a bit dark brown (not burnt brown). The consistency of oil and gram flour should neither be solid nor too liquid. [Image:Brown 1.jpg|center|550px]] Add half a litre of water and turmeric powder.  Allow it to boil for 2-3 mins.  Add salt.  Add the potatoes and lotus stalk (since these veggies take time to soften).  Add the french beans, green peas, cluster beans, and cauliflower florets.  Smash the kokum with soft hands. Add the water along with kokum, and the remaining half litre of water. Add the eggplant and okra; they may get smashed if added earlier. Many ladies fry okra in oil and make it crisp so that they don't break in kadhi, but fry them occasionally depending on their freshness. Heat 2 tsp of oil and add red chili powder. Turn off the flame, sprinkle over Kadhi and garnish it with coriander leaves. Serve. Sindhi kadhi goes with rice, spicy potato wedges and sweet boondi as side dishes, but you could also eat it as is.
